Award.AwardTitle: NSF CPS: Student Travel Grant Cyber-Physical Systems Week 2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal is to enable students from educational institutions in the United States to attend the CPSWeek 2017 collection of conferences, which are to be held April 18-21, 2017, in Pittsburgh, PA. CPSWeek is an annual international multi-conference for Cyber-Physical Systems, comprising five major multi-day conferences, five one-day workshops, and four one-day tutorials. CPSWeek is the premier conference for cyber physical systems research, and and this year's event will bring more than 700 researchers and attendees. The conferences moves from country to country each year. Attending the conference will provide students with a unique opportunity to listen and learn from the keynote speeches, presentations, posters and demos on cutting edge topics on cyber-physical systems, and to network with both leaders and other young researchers in this area. This is the tenth in the series of CPSWeek conferences.

CPS research is expected to have positive societal impacts in many areas, including transportation, energy, agriculture, water/sewage treatment, environmental management and manufacturing systems. These systems must operate safely, dependably, securely, efficiently and respond to events in real time. A key feature of CPS research is the requirement to cooperate across disciplines such as computer science, computer architecture and hardware, material science and sensor design, software engineering, networking, and control engineering. In this inherently interdisciplinary field, where collaborations are essential, meeting other researchers is especially important. Strong participation in this event, especially among students (our next generation of researchers) is important to maintaining and advancing CPS research in the US. The proposal includes a mechanism for student selection based on a research statement and letter from student department. Priority will be given to under represented minority students studying in the US and to those not presenting at the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For CPS Week 2017, we were able to partially fund travel for 40 students.  We had 67 applicants and 41 awards.  8 applicants were from outside of the US (2 Australia, 4 Europe, 1 China, 1 Canada).  It's hard to tell for sure, but it seems like 4 GEM candidates and 9 women. The attached document shows the distribution of who was funded and from which Universities.  Each student was able to attend HSCC, ICCPS, IPSN, IoTDI and RTAS, 11 workshops, a localization competition, an autonomous driving competition (F1/10), tutorials and various exhibitions from both industry and academia.  Altogether, the CPSWeek program covers a multitude of complementary aspects of CPS, and re-unites the leading researchers in this dynamic field.  The conference took place in the David Lawrence Convention Center situated in downtown Pittsburgh with more than 700 participants from more than two dozen countries.



The intellectual merit of the proposed activity was that it provided a stimulus for sustained research in the CPS community, as well as increased number of applications in other fields of science and engineering.


The broader impact resulting from NSF support was that we were able to encourage a broader and more diverse group of students (than those who are already able to attend major conferences in the field) to pursue research careers in CPS. A directed effort has been made to attract faculty and students from under-represented Universities to attend this conference.
